Usually thieves nowadays works in big gangs, so the more interesting question is whether we could generalize it for any number of thieves in some ways (might matter, too, in computer science regarding memory allocation running in parallel, doesn't it).
The simple proof for it would be, we know for N=1 thieves, a fair separation is trivial with 0 cuts. We know it works for N=2 thieves with at most N cuts. So, if I were professor I would now write: The rest will follow by inductive logic and is kept for the reader as an exercise 🙂
But, seriously, how would that work in reality?
I guess, it's upper bounded to 2 * d * N cuts for N=2^d thieves via a divide and conquer strategies (just group into 2 halfs of the gang, apply original solution and then divide further recursively). I have no real good intuition about how it works if non powers of 2. (Is that somehow connected to the chessboard problem?)
We probably also can't take just the Borsak-Ulam theorem to prove an existence in the N <> 2^d cases. I mean, we would need something proving that N points are mapped to the same origin. Would it work on manifolds with gender of N (wholes?) if we construct a clever mapping to such a surface?
For at least in computer science, we probably can ensure to have N=2^d processors or threads in case (not so sure if we regard thieves e.g. as different users and want to find an optimal storage solution for them for different entities), so should be a bit less of a practical problem. But in math we are more interested in the non practical problems, aren't we?

Because which thief the first piece goes to does not matter, and on each piece boundary the thief it belongs to switches (because otherwise, there would not need to be such a cut), brute-forcing the solution should have a runtime of (n/2)^(j-1), where n is the length of the necklace and j is the amount of jewel types (and thus cuts), because the positional candidates for the first (j-1) cuts, all located before n/2, can be iterated over, but the last cut needs to be positioned in a way that the overall jewel counts per thief are equal.
Mocking it up in python-styled pseudocode, we'd have:
nl = list of enumerated jewels
j = max(nl) # here just 2
n = len(nl)
for i in range(n//2):
j = n//2 +i
if check(nl,i,j):
return [i,j]
where check takes in the necklace and proposed cuts and verifies them.
in a more general case, you might do something like this:
nl = list of enumerated jewels
j = max(nl)
n = len(nl)
return solve(nl,j,n,n//2,[])
def solve(nl,j,n,remainder,solution): # in actual Python, this block'd need to precede the other to be available as a function definition
if remainder == 0:
if check(nl,solution):
return solution
else:
for i in range(solution[-1]+1,remainder): # cutting length of 0 is nonsensical, because that would mean the preceding segment would just be longer
newRemainder = n-(solution[-1]+remainder)
newSolution = solution+[i]
proposal = solve(nl,j,n,newRemainder,newSolution)
if proposal: # proposal is None if there is no solution to be found in the current branch, None is Falsey
return proposal

That's the breakdown of calculus when trying to solve problems with too many variables, for example finding the impact location of a projectile including air resistance which itself is made up of temperature, density, humidity etc. All solutions are approximations therefor calculus can't solve the problem elegantly.
Here's my question: perhaps there is an analogous solution like the Borsuk-Ulam theory if say the solutions to that calculus problem w/ air resistance can be mapped to a N dimensional manifold. Perhaps different regions of that manifold could represent different components of the "ideal" or "pure" solution. Maybe one sub dimension represents air temperature while another humidity. In this way a certain temperature would imply a certain humidity and lead to a cleaner solution simply by finding the antipodal point one variable corresponds to. A solution like this would avoid the ugly approximations using differential equations. To solve a complex trajectory problem you'd just index into this manifold of possible solutions to find the one that works.
Then here's the kicker, would such a solution when taken even further to include changes in temperature and humidity over the entire flight of a projectile imply somehow math had predicted any and all flight paths before hand? Another way to think about it is how taking the square root of a number always has a positive and negative value.  Square root of 4 is +2 AND -2.  So the antipodal of any point on a n dimensions sphere is always going to be its exact opposite signed coordinate.  This is because it is the only value that the square of that value is exactly the same, without the position being the same.  +n^2 = -n^2  at the same time as -n is not equal to +n. I think it would be better to present the Necklace-Cutting Problem as a riddle like this:

You and a close friend are planning to steal one of the world's most valuable necklaces from a series of unique designs featuring many elegant jewels. Your plans to steal it are nearly perfect, but your plans on dividing the profits are flawed, and involving a third party to value the gems would be too risky. If only you could turn off the alarms or see which necklace you're taking.

This is the information you have so far. Each necklace contains 4 types of jewels — sapphires, emeralds, diamonds, and rubies — but are all arranged in a seemingly random order. Each gem is separated by two golden beads. It takes 15 minutes to make one cut in the golden beads, and the police would take a little over an hour to track the two of you down, so you can only make four cuts and take only one necklace. Luckily, on each necklace, there is always an even amount of each type of jewel, so things would balance out if you could manage to divide them.

How could you divide the jewels on any possible necklace?

I am deeply suspicious of the claim that at all times two antipodal points on Earth have identical temperature and pressure. (And not just because Earth is not perfectly spherical.)  My intuition is that it lies in the assumption that temperature and pressure are continuous. What does that mean? Weather across the planet is not instantaneously driven by the same "function". Rather local conditions are driven by both local forces and by the previous conditions in other areas (e.g. Jet Stream) that have certainly may have global effects, but only after time passes. So I don't think it is correct to say temperature and pressure are continuous *worldwide*.

Higher-dimensional sphere's don't exist, because three-dimensional space doesn't exist. Take a cylinder -- usually thought of as a three-dimensional object --, it can be expressed in two terms: height (if you will), and circumference. Where is the third dimension!? It doesn't exist! It's a mathematical fiction. Dimensions are metrical, not substantial. Time consists of one dimension: whatever unit you might take. Space too, consists of only one dimension: SPACE! Don't confuse coordinates with dimensions, they're not the same! Take it from a Dollard-aficionado.

I struggled to watch this compared to the original video, and I think that delisting the original is a loss.

A key part of why your videos are so engrossing, easy to follow and ultimately so educational is the fact that they have a definite "narrative", and they generally don't explicitly identify a piece of maths until you've been gently guided to "discovering" it yourself. The original "Who else cares about topology" video was a fantastic example of this.

In this video the narrative is disjointed, partly emphasised by the fact you have to literally "break the immersion" and say "okay, that's <x>, now let's look at <completely unrelated thing y>". That, to me, is a lot more reminiscent of the traditional maths education that I'm not used to finding in your videos.

Having said that, I am sure this video has a lot of value to people who aren't me: The comments are an example that I'm definitely in the minority of your viewerbase who feels this way. I do think that you should restore the original video, however; It is still one of my favourite pieces of YouTube maths education (along with to the original "Who cares about topology?" video, which is still how I introduce new folk to your channel) and I feel it's an injustice to your legacy as a maths educator to remove it in favour of this version.

I suppose Borsuk Ulam also applies when you transform a circle onto a line. In that case, the proof is simpler. Each point on the circle maps to a single number. Now consider 2 points opposite each other on the circle. One maps lower than the other. Now suppose they both rotate simultaneously. One point must increase to the other’s mapping, and the other must decrease. Intuitively, at some point in that process these numbers must cross paths and be equal.

That is circles that contain both p and its antipodal point. I remember the Vsauce proof to be particularly compelling. They did x and y separate, first finding a continuous curve/loop of antipodal points where x(p) - x(-p) = 0, then going around that to find at least one antipodal pair where y(p) - y(-p) = 0. Very Intermediate Value Theorem. I was trying to decide quick in my head if one proof had a more restrictive setup than the other, or if the proofs are equivalent.
One of my favorite Intermediate Value Theorem proofs is with the square table with uneven legs and/or an uneven floor. I blew away my coworkers in the break room with that one. It’s even more fun because we have circular tables, with the legs in a square, so the balanced table isn’t even out of orientation with the room. It’s also true that a rectangular table can be rotated to be balanced, but the proof is harder and I don’t know it. The IVT is my favorite theorem because it is obvious to most people, because we understand continuity instinctually from experiencing the physical world, even if most people can’t describe it precisely. But it is so powerful and can prove crazy, non-obvious things.
